page.title: 2018–19 World Boxing Super Series – bantamweight division

revision.text:
The '''2018–19 World Boxing Super Series – [[bantamweight]] division''' is a [[World Boxing Super Series]] professional boxing tournament taking place between October 2018 and May 2019 in several countries. The Super Series features 8 top-rated bantamweight boxers in a single-elimination tournament. The tournament was organized by Comosa AG.{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/boxing/story/_/id/23451422/world-boxing-super-series-gets-second-season-add-single-elimination-tournaments|title=World {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox alpine ski racer | name = Bernadette Schild | image = Bernadette Schild Austrian Championships 2008.jpg | image_size = 210px | caption = Schild in March 2008 | country = | disciplines = [[Slalom skiing|Slalom]] | nickname = | club = Skiklub Dienten | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|1|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Zell am See]], [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]], [[Austria]] | death_date = | death_place = | height = 1.65 m | wcdebut = 14 March [[2008 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2008]] (age 18) | retired = | website = [http://www.bernadetteschild.com/en/ bernadetteschild.com] | olympicteams = 2 – ([[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|2014]], [[Alpine skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics|2018]]) | olympicmedals = 0 | olympicgolds = | worldsteams = 2 – ([[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2013|2013]], [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2017|2017]]) | worldsmedals = 0 | worldsgolds = | wcseasons = 9th – ([[2011 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2011]]–[[2019 Alpine Skiing World Cup|19]]) | wcwins = 0 | wcpodiums = 7 – (7 [[Slalom skiing|SL]]) | wcoveralls = 0 – ''(14th in [[2018 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2018]])'' | wctitles = 0 – ''(5th in [[Slalom skiing|SL]], [[2018 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2018]])'' | show-medals = yes | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Sport|Women's [[alpine skiing]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{AUT}}}} {{Medal|Competition|[[World Junior Alpine Skiing Championships|Junior World Championships]]}} {{Medal|Gold|2008 [[Formigal]]|Slalom}} {{Medal|Silver|2009 [[Gudiberg|Garmisch]]|Slalom}} }} '''Bernadette Schild''' (born 2 January 1990) is a [[FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|World Cup]] [[Alpine skiing|alpine ski racer]] from Austria.http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/613.html?competitorid=121239§or=AL&type=st-WC Born in [[Zell am See]], [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]], Schild specializes in [[slalom skiing|slalom]] and made her World Cup debut in March [[2008 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2008]] at [[Bormio]]. She attained her first World Cup podium in March [[2013 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2013]], a second place in slalom at [[Lenzerheide]]. Her second podium came nine months later, a third-place finish at [[Courchevel]] in December. She is a younger sister of the champion skier [[Marlies Schild|Marlies Raich]] (b. 1981);http://www.amersports.com/media/news/success_made_by_marlies/ they twice shared a podium during the [[2014 Alpine Skiing World Cup|2014]] season, at Courchevel in December and [[Kranjska Gora]] in February.{{cite news|url=http://skiracing.com/stories/hansdotter-finally-gets-a-win-as-shiffrin-lets-one-go/|magazine=Ski Racing |last=Mintz|first=Geoff |title=Hansdotter finally gets a win, as Shiffrin lets one go |date=2 February 2014 |accessdate=8 February 2014}} At the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics|2014 Olympics]], Schild was fourth after the first run in the [[Alpine skiing at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Women's slalom|slalom]], but failed to finish the second. In June 2016, she married her trainer, Armin Wierer. ==World Cup results== ===Season standings=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center" !Season !! Age !! Overall !! Slalom !! Giant
slalom !! Super-G !! {{Infobox film | name = Bloodsport | image = Bloodsport (movie poster).jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Newt Arnold]] | producer = {{plainlist| * Mark DiSalle }} | screenplay = {{plainlist| * Christopher Cosby * Mel Friedman * [[Sheldon Lettich]] }} | story = Sheldon Lettich | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]] * [[Donald Gibb]] * [[Leah Ayres]] * [[Norman Burton]] * [[Roy Chiao]] * [[Forest Whitaker]] * [[Bolo Yeung]] }} | music = [[Paul Hertzog]] | cinematography = [[David Worth (cinematographer)|David Worth]] | editing = Carl Kress | distributor = [[The Cannon Group]], [[UGC (cinema operator)|U.G.C. Worldwide Distribution]] | released = {{Film date|1988|02|26}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $1.5–2.3 million{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Bloodsport#tab=summary|title=Bloodsport|work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|accessdate=June 17, 2014}} | gross = $65 million{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Anne|authorlink1=Anne Thompson (film critic)|title=Punch Lineage|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-08-27/entertainment/8901080305_1_van-damme-kickboxing-karate-kid|website=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=October 15, 2016|date=August 27, 1989}} }} '''''Bloodsport''''' is a 1988 American [[martial arts film]] directed by [[Newt Arnold]]. It stars [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]], [[Donald Gibb]], [[Leah Ayres]], and [[Bolo Yeung]]. The film is partly based on unverified claims made by [[martial arts|martial artist]] [[Frank Dux]].{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=John|title=NINJA: Hero or Master Fake? : Others Kick Holes in Fabled Past of Woodland Hills Martial Arts Teacher|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-05-01/local/me-3111_1_american-martial-arts|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=15 October 2016|date=May 1, 1988}}{{cite news|title=FILM; Jean-Claude Van Damme, the, uh, Actor?|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 4, 1994|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/04/movies/film-jean-claude-van-damme-the-uh-actor.html|accessdate=August 8, 2010|first=David|last=Richards}}{{cite journal | last = Cater | first = Dave | title = Bloodsport – The Ultimate Martial Arts Movie | journal = Inside Kung Fu Presents the Complete Guide to Ninja Training |pages = 38–47 | date = May 1987 }} It sold well at the [[box office]], grossing $65 million on a budget of $1.5–2.3 million. ''Bloodsport'' was one of Van Damme's first starring films and showcased his athletic abilities. It has since become a [[cult film]]. ==Plot== U.S. Army Captain Frank Dux has trained from his youth in the ways of [[ninjutsu]] under his [[sensei]] Senzo Tanaka. He wants to take the place of Tanaka's deceased son Shingo in the illegal martial arts tournament ''Kumite'' in [[Hong Kong]], in order to honor his sensei. As a young boy, Dux and a group of his friends broke into Tanaka's home to steal a [[katana]], but Dux was apprehended while returning the katana to its place. Impressed by Dux's honesty and lack of fear, Senzo trained him together with Shingo. After Shingo's death, Senzo agreed to train Dux as a member of the Tanaka clan. When Dux's superiors learn of his invitation to the Kumite, they refuse to let him go. Dux goes [[absent without leave]] before saying goodbye to his sensei and leaving for Hong Kong. Two [[United States Army Criminal Investigation Command|Criminal Investigation Command]] (CID) officers, Helmer and Rawlins, are assigned to track down and arrest Dux for [[desertion]]. After arriving in Hong Kong, Dux befriends American fighter Ray Jackson and Victor Lin, who becomes the manager of Jackson and Dux. The two Americans and Chong Li—the ruthless Kumite champion—all make it through the first day of the Kumite. Dux earns the enmity of Li after breaking his record for the fastest knockout. He becomes involved with American journalist Janice Kent, who attempts to investigate the secrets of Kumite but is shocked by its violence. On the second day of the tournament, Jackson is matched against Li. Although Jackson gains the upper hand, he gloats instead of finishing Li off. Li recovers and brutally beats Jackson, landing him in hospital. Dux vows to avenge Jackson. Kent tries to convince Dux to pull out of the tournament for his own safety, but he refuses. On the last day of the competition, Dux is cornered by Helmer and Rawlins, but he defeats them and the local police. He promises to give himself up once the tournament is over. Dux advances to the tournament final to face Li, who alienated the audience by killing his semi-final opponent. Dux overpowers Li, but Li cheats by blinding him with a crushed salt pill. Dux uses his other senses as Senzo had taught him to overcome the handicap and defeat Li, becoming the first Western winner of the Kumite. After visiting Jackson in the hospital, he returns to the United States with the CID officers. ==Cast== * [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]] as [[Frank Dux]] * [[Bolo Yeung]] as Chong Li * [[Donald Gibb]] as Ray Jackson * [[Leah Ayres]] as Janice Kent * [[Norman Burton]] as Helmer * [[Forest Whitaker]] as Rawlins * Ken Siu as Victor Lin * [[Roy Chiao]] as Senzo Tanaka * [[Michel Qissi]] as Suan Paredes * [[Philip Chan]] as Inspector Chen ==Production== Co-writer Sheldon Lettich came up with the idea for the film.
I had known Frank Dux for a number of months before I came up with the idea for ''Bloodsport''. Frank told me a lot of tall tales, most of which turned out to be bullshit. But his stories about participating in this so-called "Kumite" event sounded like a great idea for a movie. There was one guy who he introduced me to, named Richard Bender, who claimed to have actually been at the Kumite event and who swore everything Frank told me was true. A few years later this guy had a falling-out with Frank, and confessed to me that everything he told me about the Kumite was a lie; Frank had coached him in what to say.{{cite web|last1=Stewart|first1=Brian|title=Q & A with Sheldon Lettich By Marco A. S. Freitas (Guest Post)|url=http://asianmoviepulse.com/2012/11/q-a-with-sheldon-lettich-by-marco-a-s-freitas-guest-post/|website=Asian Movie Pulse|accessdate=1 September 2015}}
Producer Mark Di Salle said he was looking for "a new martial arts star who was a ladies' man, [but Van Damme] appeals to both men and women. He's an American hero who fights for justice the American way and kicks the stuffing out of the bad guys." ''Bloodsport'' is one of the few films featuring scenes filmed inside [[Kowloon Walled City]] before its destruction.{{cite web|title=Popular Culture|url=http://cityofdarkness.co.uk/category/popular_culture/|website=Cityofdarkness.co.uk|accessdate=1 September 2015}} ==Release== The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reports a U.S. box office gross of $11.7 million against a budget of $2.3 million.{{cite web|last=Klady|first=Leonard|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-01-08/entertainment/ca-258_1_box-office/2 |title=Box Office Champs, Chumps : The hero of the bottom line was the 46-year-old 'Bambi' - Page 2 |work= Los Angeles Times |date=January 8, 1989|accessdate=July 23, 2012}} According to ''[[The Chicago Tribune]]'', the film pulled in $65 million worldwide, including $15 million in the U.S. and Canada, making it Cannon Group's most profitable film of 1988. ''Bloodsport'' was released on [[VHS]], selling 150,000 units by 1989. Warner Brothers released a [[DVD]] of the film in the United States on October 1, 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/movies/bloodsport/dvd-487697|title=Bloodsport|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=June 20, 2015}} ===Critical reception=== [[Rotten Tomatoes]], a [[review aggregator]], reports that the film received positive reviews from 33% of the 18 surveyed critics; the average rating was 4.3 out of 10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bloodsport/|title=Bloodsport (1988)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=June 17, 2014}} Leonard Klady of the ''Los Angeles Times'' wrote, "Hacking through the jungle of cliche and reservoir of bad acting in ''Bloodsport'' [...] are some pretty exciting matches."{{cite news|title= 'Bloodsport': A Blow for Cliches|publisher= Los Angeles Times|date=February 29, 1988|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1988-02-29/entertainment/ca-118_1_film-reviewer|accessdate=September 10, 2010 | first=Leonard | last=Klady}} Van Damme was nominated for a [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst New Star]], but lost out to [[Ronald McDonald]] in ''[[Mac and Me]]''.{{cite web|url=http://razzies.com/asp/content/XcNewsPlus.asp?cmd=view&articleid=28|title=1988 Archive|work=[[Golden Raspberry Awards]]|accessdate=2014-10-11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193735/http://www.razzies.com/asp/content/XcNewsPlus.asp?cmd=view&articleid=28|archivedate=March 4, 2016}} ==Soundtrack== {{unreferencedsect|date=January 2018}} ''Bloodsport''{{'}}s soundtrack score was composed by [[Paul Hertzog]], who also composed another Jean-Claude Van Damme film titled ''[[Kickboxer (film)|Kickboxer]]''. The soundtrack contains the songs "Fight to Survive" and "On My Own", both performed by [[Stan Bush]]. Bush's songs are replaced on the soundtrack with alternate versions sung by [[Paul Delph]], who was nominated for a [[Grammy]] for this work. The film plays the song "Steal the Night" by [[Michael Bishop (bassist)|Michael Bishop]] during a scene where Dux runs from Helmer and Rawlins. The song was not released until the mid-2000s, as a single containing a vocal and instrumental version. On June 26, 2007, [[Perseverance Records]] released a limited edition CD of the soundtrack including, for the first time, the original film versions of the Stan Bush songs. ==Legacy== Since its release, ''Bloodsport'' has become a [[cult film]].{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2012/08/the-must-see-action-movies-from-the-stars-of-the-expendables-2/jean-claude-van-damme|title=The Must-See Action Movies From The Stars Of "The Expendables 2"|last=Serafino|first=Jason|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=16 August 2012|accessdate=October 20, 2016}} It was followed by three sequels: ''[[Bloodsport II: The Next Kumite]]'' (1996), ''[[Bloodsport III]]'' (1997) and ''[[Bloodsport 4: The Dark Kumite]]'' (1999). They were released direct-to-video, and Jean-Claude Van Damme did not appear in any of them. A remake of ''Bloodsport'' was reported to be in planning in 2011. [[Phillip Noyce]] was attached to direct a screenplay by [[Robert Mark Kamen]]. The main character was supposed to be an American [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]] veteran competing in a [[vale tudo]] tournament in Brazil.{{cite web|last1=Goodridge|first1=Mike|title=Pressman signs Noyce for Bloodsport; lands Venice slot for Moth Diaries|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/production/pressman-signs-noyce-for-bloodsport-lands-venice-slot-for-moth-diaries/5027674.article|website=[[Screen Daily]]|accessdate=15 October 2016|date=17 May 2011}} ''[[V for Vendetta]]'' director [[James McTeigue]] was attached to the project by 2013, and the filming was to be done in Australia and Brazil.{{cite web|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Relativity Reboots Jean-Claude Van Damme’s ‘Bloodsport’|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/relativity-reboots-jean-claude-van-dammes-bloodsport-exclusive-1200567503/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=October 15, 2016|date=July 24, 2013}} ''Bloodsport'' was covered in the 132nd episode of the [[Earwolf|Earwolf Network]] movie criticism podcast ''[[How Did This Get Made?]]'', released on March 23, 2016.{{cite web |title=Bloodsport: LIVE! |url=http://www.earwolf.com/episode/bloodsport-live/ |website=Earwolf |accessdate=8 November 2018 |date=March 13, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|60em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0092675}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|bloodsport}} * {{Mojo title|bloodsport}} * {{Amg movie|6184}} {{Bloodsport (film)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bloodsport (Film)}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1980s martial arts films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American martial arts films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Bloodsport films]] [[Category:Films set in 1979]] [[Category:Films set in 1980]] [[Category:Films set in 1981]] [[Category:Films set in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Films shot in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Karate films]] [[Category:Martial arts tournament films]] [[Category:Underground fighting films]] [[Category:Sports in fiction]] [[Category:Films based on newspaper and magazine articles]] [[Category:Golan-Globus films]]

부천종합운동장 | nickname = | logo_image = | image = Bucheonstadium3.JPG | image_size = 220 | caption = | fullname = Bucheon Stadium | location = Sosa-ro, [[Wonmi-gu]], [[Bucheon]], [[Gyeonggi-do]], [[Republic of Korea]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.50256|126.799135|display=inline,title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} | built = | opened = 25 March 2001 | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Bucheon|Bucheon City]] | operator = Bucheon Public Amenities Care Corporation | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Jeju United FC|Bucheon SK]] (2001–2005)
[[Bucheon FC 1995]] (2008–present) | seating_capacity = 35,456 | dimensions = }} '''Bucheon Stadium''' ({{lang-ko|부천종합운동장}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Bucheon]], [[Gyeonggi-do]], [[South Korea]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and has been the home stadium of [[Bucheon FC 1995]] since 2008. The stadium holds about 38,000 people (34,456 seats) and was opened in 2001. ==External links== * [http://www.bfc1995.com/ Bucheon FC 1995 Official website] {{ko icon}} * [http://www.bcs.or.kr/ Bucheon City website] {{ko icon}} {{Bucheon FC 1995}} {{Jeju United FC}} [[Category:Football venues in South Korea]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in South Korea]] [[Category:Sports venues in Gyeonggi Province]] [[Category:Jeju United FC]] [[Category:Bucheon FC 1995]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bucheon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:2001 establishments in South Korea]] {{SouthKorea-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{more citations needed|date=June 2012}}{{Infobox UK Racecourse | Name = Chepstow | Image = [[File:Chepstow Racing & Events logo.jpg|200px]] | Caption = | Website = http://www.chepstow-racecourse.co.uk | Location = [[Chepstow]], [[Monmouthshire]] | Coordinates = {{coord|51|39|23|N|2|41|19|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=it}} | Owner = [[Arena Racing Company]] | Channel = [[At The Races]] | CourseType = [[Flat racing|Flat]]
[[National Hunt]] | Prev = [[Cheltenham Racecourse|Cheltenham]] | Next = [[Chester Racecourse|Chester]] }} '''Chepstow Racecourse''' is a [[thoroughbred horse racing]] [[racecourse|course]] located just north of the town of [[Chepstow]] in [[Monmouthshire]], [[Wales]], near the southern end of the [[Wye Valley]] and close to the border with England. It is one of 16 racecourses operated by the Arena Racing Company and is home of the richest race in Wales, the Coral Welsh Grand National. ==Track and facilities== [[File:Chepstow Racecourse.jpg|thumb|250px|Chepstow racecourse]] The track is a roughly oval circuit of just under {{convert|2|mi|m}}. It is a left-handed undulating course, used for both flat and jump racing. The finishing straight is about {{convert|5|furlong}} in length, with five fences on the chase course to be jumped. There are eleven fences on a complete circuit. There is also a straight mile course. There are 32 fixtures in the 2017 calendar year including the new two-day Totepool Jumps Season Opener with £300,000 of prize money on Saturday 14th and Sunday 15 October. This meeting features the £50,000 Grade Three Tote Silver Trophy (Handicap Hurdle) and the £35,000 Grade Two Totepool Persian War Novices' Hurdle. The £150,000 Coral Welsh Grand National takes place on Wednesday 27 December 2017. This meeting also features the Coral Future Champions Finale Juvenile Hurdle, one of only three Grade One juvenile hurdles in the calendar. Chepstow is one of three racecourses in Wales, the others being at [[Bangor-on-Dee racecourse|Bangor-on-Dee]] and at [[Ffos Las racecourse|Ffos Las]]. It is also used as a venue for numerous other indoor and outdoor events, such as concerts, weddings and conferences.[http://www.chepstow-racecourse.co.uk/ Chepstow racecourse website] ==History== Several places in South Wales had race meetings in the late nineteenth century and there had been racing at [[St Arvans]], very close to the present course, between 1892 and 1914. In 1925 a group of ten South Wales gentry and businessmen, that included [[Courtenay Morgan, 1st Viscount Tredegar]] who was also [[Lord-Lieutenant of Monmouthshire]], and [[Lord Queenborough]];{{cite web|url=http://www.talkhorseracing.co.uk/guides/chepstow_racecourse.html|title=Chepstow Racecourse|publisher=talkhorseracing.co.uk|accessdate=2012-06-26}} formed a company to purchase [[Piercefield House]], and lay out a new racecourse in its estate. Despite struggling to raise enough cash, the racecourse was opened on 6 August 1926. The first race was a two-year-old seller won by [[Lord Harewood]]'s colt Conca D'Oro, the 7-4 favourite. The two day flat race meeting had good prize money and was termed "The Welsh [[Glorious Goodwood|Goodwood]]".Lucas, Pat. 1976. Fifty Years of Racing at Chepstow. SBN 901906 14 X The course nearly had to close down immediately after the first meeting and survived only thanks to a large bank loan guaranteed by the directors. Unforeseen extra costs in laying it out meant that it struggled financially for the first ten years of its existence and yet more contributions were needed from the directors. The first jump racing took place in March 1927. Since then the course has been used for flat racing in the summer and jumping in the winter. To begin with, the flat racing was more prestigious, with the Welsh [[Derby]], [[Epsom Oaks|Oaks]] and [[St Leger]] being run for good prize money. In 1933, at a two-day meeting, the multiple champion jockey [[Gordon Richards]] won eleven consecutive races at Chepstow – all six races on the first day and the first five races on the next, before being beaten in a close finish in the final race of the meeting. ===RAF Chepstow=== [[File:Chepstow racecourse from the Wyndcliff (9368).jpg|thumb|The racecourse as seen from the [[Wyndcliff]], with the [[Severn Bridge]] in the background.]] During [[World War II|the Second World War]], the entire site became designated as '''RAF Chepstow''', an operational outpost of [[RAF St. Athan]], [[No. 32 Maintenance Unit RAF]]. Equipped with only a grass runway in the centre of the course, additional aircraft accommodation for bombers was created at Oakgrove on the opposite side of the road, accessed by stopping the traffic to allow the aircraft to cross. Types stationed on the course during the war included:{{cite web|url=http://www.piercefieldpark.co.uk/varticle38.aspx|title=Chepstow Racecourse and the Royal Airforce 1941/42|author=Neil Widdas|publisher=piercefieldpark.co.uk|year=2005|accessdate=2012-06-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107181549/http://www.piercefieldpark.co.uk/varticle38.aspx|archivedate=7 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} *[[Boulton Paul Defiant]] *[[Hawker Hurricane]] *[[Armstrong Whitworth Whitley]] *[[Vickers Wellington]] *[[Bristol Blenheim]] ===Postwar=== After the war and the demise of the nearby [[Caerleon]] course, the [[Welsh National]] was transferred to Chepstow in 1949. From then on, [[National Hunt racing]] overtook flat racing as the dominant activity as a string of good class horses and top trainers and jockeys contested the race. The three and three-quarter mile race, more recently known as the Coral Welsh National, owes much to the support of the bookmaking firm for establishing it as one of the major events in the National Hunt calendar. It have sponsored it for over forty years, making it the second longest continuous race sponsorship. [[File:Chepstow Racecourse - geograph.org.uk - 1286216.jpg|thumb|250px|Horse racing at Chepstow racecourse]] The opening of the [[Severn Bridge]] and the completion of the [[M4 motorway]] made the course more accessible to English racegoers.{{cite book |editor1-first=John |editor1-last=Davies|editor1-link=John Davies (historian)|editor2-first=Nigel |editor2-last=Jenkins | editor2-link=Nigel Jenkins| editor3-first=Baines |editor3-last=Menna|editor4-first=Peredur I. |editor4-last=Lynch|title=The Welsh Academy Encyclopaedia of Wales |year=2008 |publisher=University of Wales Press |location=Cardiff |page=376 |isbn=978-0-7083-1953-6}} The Clay family, which had bought Piercefield House in 1861, were involved with the management course since its formation. Listed on the [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM stock market]] as a [[Public limited company|plc]] in the late 1990s, [[Stanley Clarke (businessman)|Sir Stanley Clarke]] built up an 80% stake in the company and then [[reverse takeover|reversed]] his existing [[Northern Racing]] racecourse holdings into the shell. Clarke took over as executive chairman of the Racecourse Company in 2000, resigning in 2003 before his 2004 death from [[cancer]]. Chepstow is now part of the [[Arena Racing Company]], also called ARC Racing and Leisure Group a private UK company, created in 2012 by the merger of [[Arena Leisure]] and [[Northern Racing]]. It owns and operates several racecourses.{{cite web|title=Arena Racing Company|website=arenaracingcompany.co.uk/news/story/71}} == Notable races == {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! style="width:70px" |Month ! style="width:80px" |DOW ! Race Name ! style="width:60px" |Type ! style="width:70px" | '''Grade''' ! style="width:80px" |Distance ! style="width:50px" |Age/Sex |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|1|October}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Silver Trophy Handicap Hurdle]] | style="text-align:center" |Hurdle | style="text-align:center" | Grade 3 | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3914|2m 3½f }} | style="text-align:center" |4yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|2|October}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Smerdon Tree Services Novices' Chase]] | style="text-align:center" |Chase | style="text-align:center" | Listed | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3914|2m 3½f }} | style="text-align:center" |4yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3|October}} | style="text-align:center" |Sunday | [[Persian War Novices' Hurdle]] | style="text-align:center" |Hurdle | style="text-align:center" | Grade 2 | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3914|2m 3½f }} | style="text-align:center" |4yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|4|December}} | style="text-align:center" |27th | [[Welsh Grand National]] | style="text-align:center" |Chase | style="text-align:center" | Grade 3 | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|5934|3m 5f 110y}} | style="text-align:center" |4yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|5|December}} | style="text-align:center" |27th | [[Finale Juvenile Hurdle]] | style="text-align:center" |Hurdle | style="text-align:center" | Grade 1 | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3319|2m 110y}} | style="text-align:center" |3yo only |} ;Discontinued races * [[Golden Daffodil Stakes]] (''last run in 2005'') ==Other events== Chepstow racecourse hosts concerts after evening race meetings: * [[Madness (band)|Madness]] played at the course in June 2013 and July 2015. * [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] performed in June 2014. * [[UB40]] appeared in May 2015. * [[Simply Red]] performed in 2016 * [[Peter Andre]] performed in 2016 * [[Feeder (band)|Feeder]] performed in 2017 ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Chepstow Racecourse}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091022140706/http://www.bettingpro.com/category/Racing/Chepstow-Racing-Tips--Guide-to-UK-Jumps-Racing/ Chepstow Course Guide] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070318223533/http://www.gg.com/chepstow Course guide on GG.COM] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060907133555/http://www1.attheraces.com/course.asp?cid=38 Course guide on At The Races] {{Horse racing in Great Britain}} [[Category:Horse racing venues in Wales]] [[Category:Chepstow]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1926]]

revision.text:
{{Notability|date=June 2010}} '''Cyclops''' is a computer system co-invented by the British inventor Bill Carlton of [[Great Britain]] and Margaret Parnis England of Malta,<ref>Roberts, John. [https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cyclops-has-company-as-machine-moves-to-replace-net-cord-judge-1583317.html Cyclops has company as machine moves to replace net cord judge]. ''[[The Independent]]'' (23 November 1995)</ref> which is used on the [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP]] and [[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]] professional [[tennis]] tours as an [[Electronic line judge (tennis)|electronic line judge]] to help determine whether a serve is in or out.
The system, which must be activated by the service line umpire before each serve, projects five or six [[infra-red]] horizontal beams of light along the court 10 mm above the ground. One beam covers the good (short) side of the service line and others cover the fault (long) side. If a served ball hits the first beam, the other beams are turned off, while a long serve will break one of the other beams. A long serve is indicated by an audible signal. Obvious long serves that go beyond Cyclops' beams are called by the service line umpire. The system is tuned before and during each tournament by a representative of the company which rents the system. This representative stays through the tournament and confers with tournament officials afterwards to determine any problems which may have arisen. The system has been constantly refined to improve accuracy, although no statistics on its efficacy are available.<ref>Greenman, Catherine. [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/31/technology/for-us-open-tennis-a-service-line-umpire-that-never-blinks.html For U.S. Open Tennis, a Service Line Umpire That Never Blinks]. ''[[The New York Times]]'' (August 31, 2000)</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/tennis/features/newsid_3001000/3001768.stm ''Sport Academy:'' Cyclops and speed guns] [[BBC]] website</ref>
The Cyclops computer system was introduced to the [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Championships]] in 1980 and the [[US Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] in 1981, and was also used at the [[Australian Open]]. In 2007 it was removed from Wimbledon's Centre Court and Court No. 1 to allow the use of the [[Hawk-Eye]] system first introduced at the U.S. Open in 2006.<ref>Smith, Stevie. [http://www.monstersandcritics.com/sport/tennis/article_1296402.php/Cyclops_ousted_by_HawkEye_at_Wimbledon Cyclops ousted by HawkEye at Wimbledon] ''Tennis News'' (April 25, 2007)</ref> At the present time Cyclops is not used in any capacity at any of the Grand Slam events.
A famous moment involving Cyclops occurred at Wimbledon in 1980 when [[Ilie Năstase]] got down on his hands and knees to talk to the equipment to argue an "out" signal.
==See also== * [[Electronic line judge]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}} {{tennis box}}
[[Category:Tennis equipment]] [[Category:Sports officiating technology]]

The '''Deutscher Sportclub für Fußballstatistiken e.V.''', (English: ''German sports club for football statistics'') short '''DSFS''' is an association dedicated to collecting and publishing [[German football]] [[statistics]], similar to the [[RSSSF]], and is a member of the [[German Olympic Society]].
The club used to be best known for its annual publication, the ''Deutscher Fussball-Almanach'', a yearbook on German football.<ref>[https://www.weltbild.de/artikel/buch/deutscher-fussball-almanach-saison-2014-2015_20875380-1 Produkt-Beschreibung zu: Deutscher Fussball-Almanach 2014/2015] {{de icon}} [[Weltbild]] website - Book review, accessed: 23 October 2015</ref> Unlike other yearbooks, it does not so much focus on professional football, but rather covers the higher amateur leagues.<ref>[https://www.amazon.de/review/R1RARQYUQ907TE Fussball - Mehr als nur Bundesliga] {{de icon}} Amazon.de - Book review, accessed: 2 December 2008</ref>
==History== The DSFS was formed on 1 July 1971 but was only registered in 1979. It was formed by six football enthusiasts after Helmut Druwen posted an add in the ''[[Kicker (sports magazine)|kicker]]'' sport magazine looking for people interested in football statistics. Having grown to a membership of 50, another add in the ''kicker'' in 1978 pushed the membership drive ahead and in 1979 the club finally became properly registered, joining the German Olympic Society as well.<ref>[http://www.dsfs.de/index.php?id=65 Epochen] {{de icon}} DSFS website, accessed: 2 December 2008</ref>
From 1980, the club started publishing brochures and a club magazine. But after 1983, the ''DSFS'' went into decline for the first time, recovering only in 1986 from several years of inactivity.
With the re-establishment of the ''[[Regionalliga (football)|Regionalliga]]'' in German football in 1994, a reform of the clubs annual publication was started. Year by year until 2004 the contents was expanded until covering all divisions of German football on the top five levels including the top youth and women's leagues. Consequently, the name ofthis annual publication was changed to ''Deutschlands Fussball in Zahlen'' (English: ''Germanys football by numbers'').<ref>[http://fussball-kultur.org/v01/de/pub/index.html?navID=108&IDS=0ghLrtBg Deutsche Akademie für Fussball Kultur] {{de icon}} List of organisations and websites associated with football, accessed: 2 December 2008</ref>
In 1998, it was declared ''Gemeinnützig'', similar to a [[Non-profit organization]], which entitles German clubs to certain tax benefits. In 2004, the number of members was at its peak with almost 430 members. Since then the club lost several of them and now has approximately 363 members (2015 census).
As of September 2006, the clubs president is Dirk Henning.
==See also== * [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics]] * [[RSSSF]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dsfs.de/ DSFS website]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Bagwell Field at Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium | nickname = Rowdy Dowdy | image = UAB at ECU football game 2009-11-21.JPG | caption = Dowdy–Ficklen stadium in 2009 | fullname = Bagwell Field at Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium | location = Blackbeard's Alley, [[Greenville, North Carolina|Greenville]], [[North Carolina]] 27858 | coordinates = {{coord|35|35|47|N|77|21|55|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1962 | built = 1962-1963 | opened = September 21, 1963 | renovated = 1991 - $1.6 million in repairs and renovations, 2002, 2009-2010 | expanded = 1967–1968 - increased [[seating capacity]] to 20,000
1977–1978 - increased [[seating capacity]] to 35,000
1996–1998 - increased [[seating capacity]] to 43,000
2010 - increased [[seating capacity]] to 50,000 | owner = [[East Carolina University]] | operator = [[East Carolina University]] | surface = [[Cynodon_dactylon#Varieties|Tifton 419 Hybrid Bermuda]] | construction_cost = $283,387 ($2,234,553.41 in 2016 dollars) | architect = Dudley & Shoe | former_names = Ficklen Memorial Stadium (1963–1994) | tenants = [[East Carolina Pirates]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1963–present) | seating_capacity = 50,000 }} '''Bagwell Field at Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium''' is the on-campus [[American football|football]] facility for the [[East Carolina University|East Carolina]] [[East Carolina Pirates|Pirates]] in [[Greenville, North Carolina|Greenville]], [[North Carolina]]. The official capacity of the stadium is 50,000, making it the third largest college stadium in North Carolina. The record attendance for the stadium was on September 20, 2014 against the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] with 51,082 in attendance. The stadium is also the site of Spring Commencement exercises for the University.{{cite web| title = Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium | work = East Carolina Official Athletic Site | publisher = East Carolina University| year = 2008| url = http://ecupirates.cstv.com/facilities/ecu-facilities-dowdy.html| accessdate = 2009-02-10}} ==History== ===Original construction=== The initiative to build a new stadium was announced on October 7, 1961. On that day, [[List of East Carolina University administration|President]] [[Leo Jenkins]] announced to a meeting of [[Boosterism|boosters]], that a new stadium will be built to replace [[College Stadium]]. By 1962, over $280,000 was raised and Ficklen Memorial Stadium was built.{{cite web| title = Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium| work = Facilities | publisher = East Carolina Pirates| year = 2010| url = http://www.ecupirates.com/facilities/ecu-facilities-dowdy.html| accessdate = August 2, 2010}} The stadium was named for James Skinner Ficklen, the owner of Greenville's E.B. Skinner Tobacco Company. Skinner was a booster of the college, and established a scholarship fund in his name.{{cite web | title = Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium | work = Building Histories | publisher = Joyner Library | date = October 1, 2008 | url = http://media.lib.ecu.edu/archives/bldg_history.cfm?id=49 | accessdate = August 2, 2010}} The original stadium included permanent stands on the south side, a press box, and a lighting system.{{cite web | title = Growing Season - Football Stadium Expansion| work = Web Features| publisher = East Carolina University | date = June 2, 2010 | url = http://www.ecu.edu/cs-admin/mktg/stadium_expansion.cfm | accessdate = August 2, 2010}} Ficklen Memorial Stadium opened on September 21, 1963 with a win against [[1963 Wake Forest Demon Deacons football team|Wake Forest]]. The original [[seating capacity]] was 10,000. ===Early expansions=== The north side permanent seating was constructed in 1967 and 1968, increasing the capacity of the stadium to 20,000. The seats were designed by W.M. Freeman Associates from [[High Point, North Carolina|High Point]], [[North Carolina]]. The exterior of the stadium was painted in 1970 by F.A. Miller Company. The lighting system was the next item that changed. The original lighting system was replaced with six towers outside of the stadium in 1975. The cost of the new lighting system was $450,000. L.E. Wooten company built the lighting system. The next addition occurred two years later. The university added seats to the four corners increased the [[seating capacity]] to 35,000. This addition made Ficklen Memorial Stadium the third largest stadium in North Carolina. The expansion was funded by a $2.5 million drive in the spring of 1977. The three-story press box which is currently in use was built during that expansion. The press box had space for 92 writers and an entire floor for electronic media. Lastly, scoreboard with a lightbank message center was placed on the east end of the stadium. The playing surface was redone in 1983. A new drainage system, new base of gravel and sand, new treated topsoil, and a new grass—[[Cynodon_dactylon#Varieties|Tifton 419]] Hybrid Bermuda were all installed. A new sound system was built in 1988. ===1990s expansions=== [[File:DowdyFicklenStadium3.jpg|thumb|right|Dowdy–Ficklen press box side in 2008]] In 1991, $1.6 million in renovations and repairs were accomplished on the stadium. Ronald and Mary Ellen Dowdy of [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]], donated one million dollars during a fund-raising drive in 1994. Because of this donation, Ficklen Memorial Stadium was renamed Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium. Also that year the roads were improved around the stadium. A year later, Al and Debbie Bagwell of [[Lake Gaston]], [[Virginia]] donated to the East Carolina Educational Foundation. Because of this donation, the field inside the stadium was named Bagwell Field. The upper deck on the north side was completed in 1998. It increased the capacity to 40,000. This was the first [[seating capacity]] increase since 1977. A year later the club level on the north side was completed. It added 3,000 seats to the total capacity. During the expansion of the upper deck and club level, the press box received improvements. In 1999, a $2 million scoreboard was built in the east endzone. Also that year a Pirate sculpture was dedicated in the southeast area of the stadium. The three-ton bronze sculpture is over {{convert|20|ft|m}} tall. Irwin Belk gave the sculpture to the school. Jodi Hollnagel, a faculty member of the [[College of Fine Arts and Communication at East Carolina University#The School of Art and Design|School of Art]] created the sculpture.{{cite web | title = Minges Coliseum/Williams Arena| work = Building Histories | publisher = Joyner Library | date = October 1, 2008 | url = http://media.lib.ecu.edu/archives/bldg_history.cfm?id=99 | accessdate = August 2, 2010}} ===Murphy Center construction=== [[File:2011 Dowdy-Ficklen Stadium - Murphy Center.jpg|thumb|right|The Murphy Center in the west endzone.]] The $13 million Murphy Center was dedicated on September 13, 2002. It was built in the west endzone of the stadium. It connects the stadium to [[Williams Arena at Minges Coliseum]]. The {{convert|52475|sqft|m2|adj=on}} strength and conditioning, banquet rooms, sport memorabilia, and an academic enhancement center building was named for Pete and Lynn Murphy of [[Rose Hill, North Carolina|Rose Hill]], [[North Carolina]].{{cite web |author=ECU Pirates Official Athletic Site |url=http://www.ecupirates.com/facilities/?id=7 |title=Murphy Center |publisher=ecupirates.com |accessdate=2017-09-13}} ===2009–2010 expansion=== The next expansion began in December 2009. The expansion included removing the scoreboard located in the east end zone. 7,000 seats were built in its place. The seats connect the north and south sides in a horseshoe pattern. Those seats increased the capacity to 50,000. Restroom and concession stands were built under the new section. Above the east end zone, a new scoreboard was built. The high-definition scoreboard is {{convert|88|ft|m}} wide and a little over {{convert|28|ft|m}} tall. The LED portion is {{convert|84|ft|m}} wide. This makes the new scoreboard the 22nd largest scoreboard in [[Football Bowl Subdivision|NCAA Football Bowl Subdivision]]. On the north and south sides of the stadium, 10,200 chair-back seats were installed. Lastly, another scoreboard was built on the west end zone in front of the Murphy Center. The total cost of the expansion was $20 million.{{cite web| last = Gibson| first = Todd | title = ECU Set To Unveil $20M Stadium Expansion| publisher = NBC17| date = August 3, 2010| url = http://news.mync.com/site/news/story/54020/sports-ecu-set-to-unveil-20m-stadium-expansion/| accessdate = August 3, 2010}} [[File:2011 Dowdy-Ficklen Stadium (VT at ECU).jpg|thumb|center|450px|Dowdy-Ficklen in 2011]] ===2018 renovation project=== In May 2016, East Carolina revealed a $55 million renovation project for Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium, which is a portion of its athletic facilities master plan. The project, which is slated to begin construction after the 2017 football season and was to be completed in time for the 2018 football season, has been extended to a 16-18 month construction period.{{cite web |author=ECU Pirates Official Athletic Site |url=http://www.ecupirates.com/news/2017/8/31/football-dowdy-ficklen-stadium-southside-renovation-timeline-extended.aspx |title=Dowdy-Ficklen Stadium Southside Renovation Timeline Extended |publisher=ecupirates.com |accessdate=2017-09-13}} The renovation includes: * A four-story tower above the south general admission seats which will add than 1,000 premium seats through the addition of a new Club Level, Loge Boxes, and Suites. * A new field-level Club Section at the Murphy Center * A modern press box with additional space for media, including amended radio and television broadcast and production locations. * Improvements to the Ward Sports Medicine Building and Scales Field House to provide needed functional space for student-athletes.{{cite web |author=ECU Pirates Official Athletic Site |url=http://www.ecupirates.com/news/2016/4/16/Dowdy_Ficklen_Stadium_Southside_Renovation_Project_Plans_Released.aspx |title=Dowdy-Ficklen Stadium Southside Renovation Project Plans Released |publisher=ecupirates.com |accessdate=2017-09-13}} ==Marshall University plane crash== On November 14, 1970, the visiting [[Marshall University]] [[Marshall Thundering Herd football|Thundering Herd]] lost a game 17-14 to the Pirates at Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium, which ended with Marshall [[quarterback]] Ted Shoebridge controversially being called for [[intentional grounding]] on the last play of the game. Later that evening, while on approach to [[Huntington, West Virginia|Huntington]] [[Tri-State Airport]], the Marshall football team's [[Southern Airways Flight 932|plane]], which had been chartered to transport the Thundering Herd to and from Greenville, crashed, killing all 75 people on board. On December 11, 2006, a [[Commemorative plaque|plaque]] was erected at the visitors' entrance to Dowdy–Ficklen Stadium. It depicts the memorial fountain on the Marshall University campus. ==Attendance== === List of average attendance === {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|East Carolina {{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Estadio Sausalito | nickname = | image = File:Everton - Cobreloa, 23-08-2015 - Estadio Sausalito.JPG | fullname = | location = [[Viña del Mar]] , [[Chile]] | coordinates = {{Coord|33|0|51.83|S|71|32|6.84|W}} | broke_ground = | built = 1929 | opened = 8 September 1929 | reopened = 4 June 2015 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipio de Viña Del Mar | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Everton de Viña del Mar|Everton]] | seating_capacity = 22,360{{cite web|url=http://www.conmebol.com/es/copa-america-2015|title=Copa América 2015|work=conmebol.com}} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} '''Estadio Sausalito''' ({{IPA-es|sausaˈlito}}; Sausalito Stadium) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Viña del Mar]], [[Chile]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[Corporación Deportiva Everton de Viña del Mar|CD Everton]]. The stadium holds 22,360 people, was built in 1929 and completely renovated in 2015. The stadium has hosted the [[1962 FIFA World Cup|1962 World Cup]], two times the [[Copa América]] ([[1991 Copa América|1991]] and [[2015 Copa América|2015]]) and a [[FIFA U-17 World Cup]]. The name comes from the nearby Sausalito lagoon. == History == [[File:Estadio Saualito during Copa America, Jun 2015.jpg|260px|thumbnail|Estadio Sausalito before a [[2015 Copa América]] match between [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] and [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] on 20 June.]] It was built during [[Carlos Ibáñez del Campo]] government in 1929. In 1960, the stadium was practically destroyed by the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake|Valdivia earthquake]], but the rapid reconstruction financed by the municipality did that the ground was chosen as one of the venues to held the [[1962 FIFA World Cup|1962 World Cup]] where hosted all the games of the Group C as well as one during the quarterfinals and semifinals respectively. In 1991, ''Sausalito'' returned to international football, after appearing as one of the four venues in the [[1991 Copa América|Copa América]] of that year, alongside [[Santiago]], [[Valparaíso]] and [[Concepción, Chile|Concepción]]. On 19 July 2012, [[President of Chile]] [[Sebastián Piñera]] announced a reshuffle to the stadium to host the [[2015 Copa América]] and the [[2015 FIFA U-17 World Cup|FIFA U-17 World Cup]] of the same year, which started during his government and finished few days before the Copa América during [[Michelle Bachelet]] government. ==International matches== As one of the venues for the [[1962 World Cup]], the Estadio Sausalito hosted eight matches including the semi-final between [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]] and [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]]. It was also one of four venues to host matches during the [[Copa América 1991]], and it will be one of the eight venues to host matches during the [[Copa América 2015]]. ===1962 FIFA World Cup=== 19th May 2017 | dimensions = 105 x 68 m [http://www.scottishfootballleague.com/fans/ground-guides/ Ground Guides] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130061944/http://www.scottishfootballleague.com/fans/ground-guides/ |date=30 January 2012 }}, SFL. Retrieved 11 January 2012. | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Falkirk F.C.]] (2004–present)
[[Stirling University F.C.]] (2016–present)
[[East Stirlingshire F.C.]] (2018–present) | embedded = | website = {{URL|www.falkirkstadium.co.uk}} }} The '''Falkirk Stadium''' is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Falkirk]], central [[Scotland]], which is the home ground of [[Scottish Championship]] club, [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]]. The stadium has a capacity of {{SPFL-stadiums|falkirk}}{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/clubs/falkirk/ |title=Falkirk Football Club|publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |accessdate=11 November 2013}} and currently consists of three fully completed stands. The stadium was opened in 2004 with the main stand completed. It became the home of Falkirk in the same year after the club ground shared [[Ochilview Park]] for the 2003–04 season whilst the stadium was being constructed. The north and south stands were built and opened in 2005 and 2009 respectively. ==History== {{See also|Falkirk F.C.#History|label 1=History of Falkirk F.C.}} Work began on building the stadium in 2003[http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/news/local-headlines/falkirk_stadium_approved_now_work_begins_1_292118 Falkirk Stadium approved ... now work begins], ''[[Falkirk Herald]]''. 20 March 2003. Retrieved 10 January 2012. after [[Brockville Park]], the club's town centre home since 1885, was sold and demolished.[http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/news/local-headlines/163_9_million_deal_agreed_for_brockville_1_291666 £9 million deal agreed for Brockville], ''[[Falkirk Herald]]''. 19 July 2002. Retrieved 10 January 2012. The project of building the stadium was a partnership between Falkirk Football Club and [[Falkirk Council]] who set up the Falkirk Community Stadium Ltd which provided the funds to construct and run the stadium.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/7923473.stm |title=Football stadium venture to end |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=10 January 2012}} Falkirk Council estimated £6.1 million would be required for the first stage of the Community Stadium build and would contribute £3.1 million initially. The sale of Brockville Park amounted to £9 million [[pound sterling|pounds]] for the club, of which £2.8 million went towards the build, whilst £200,000 came from [[sportscotland]]. The first stage of the stadium was completed in time for the [[2004–05 in Scottish football|2004–05 football season]] and Falkirk moved in after spending the previous year [[groundshare|ground-sharing]] with local rivals, [[Stenhousemuir F.C.|Stenhousemuir]] at their [[Ochilview Park]] home. [[File:Falkirk Stadium West Stand.jpg|350px|thumb|left|The facade of the West Stand]] Falkirk's first ever game at the stadium was a friendly in July 2004 against [[Dundee F.C.|Dundee]] resulting in a 2–1 defeat.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-119911981.html |title=Bairn again but Dundee contrive to rain on the Falkirk stadium parade |first=Ewing |last=Grahame |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=26 July 2004 |accessdate=3 September 2013}} A month later the first league game was hosted in the stadium with visitors [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] drawing 1–1.[http://www.freewebs.com/waxoylfanclub/FFC/index.html News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106031528/http://www.freewebs.com/waxoylfanclub/FFC/index.html |date=6 January 2014 }}, The Falkirk Stadium. 25 July 2004. Retrieved 11 January 2012. In October 2004 construction work commenced for the building of a second stand to the north of the pitch. The stand has a capacity of 2,000. After completion, the £1.58m[http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/news/local-headlines/work_to_start_on_new_stand_1_297980 Work to start on new stand], ''[[Falkirk Herald]]''. 29 April 2004. Retrieved 12 January 2012. facility would bring the stadium's capacity to over the [[Scottish Premier League]]'s 6,000 seating criteria meaning Falkirk would be allowed automatic promotion[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/falkirk/4387279.stm Falkirk stadium gets green light], BBC Sport. 31 March 2005. Retrieved 11 January 2012. from the [[Scottish Football League First Division|First Division]]. The stand received its safety certificate in late March 2005, shortly before the SPL's deadline for a stadium which met the seating criteria. By May of the same year the north stand was fully completed.[http://www.falkirk.gov.uk/services/development/design/building_design/community_design/community_stadium.aspx Falkirk Stadium building design] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020144224/http://www.falkirk.gov.uk/services/development/design/building_design/community_design/community_stadium.aspx |date=20 October 2013 }}, Falkirk Council. Retrieved 11 June 2013. Construction of the south stand began in December 2008 by contractors Ogilvie.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/7762501.stm Work on third stand gets underway], BBC News. 3 December 2008. Retrieved 12 January 2012. A £2m pledge from Sandy Alexander, founder of [[Schuh]] and Falkirk supporter, helped fund the project. The south stand has a capacity of around 2,000 and is identical in appearance to the north stand of the stadium.[http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/falkirk.html#Falkirk%20Stadium%20-%20External%20View What's The Ground Like?], Scottish Football Grounds Guide. 22 April 2013. Retrieved 11 June 2013. It was officially opened in August 2009 in a friendly game against [[Royal Antwerp F.C.|Royal Antwerp FC]] of [[Belgium]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/8175104.stm Club debut for new stadium stand], BBC News. 30 July 2009. Retrieved 12 January 2012 This brought the capacity of the stadium to around 8,000 people without the inclusion of the temporary east stand. The [[joint venture]] that was set up between Falkirk F.C. and [[Falkirk Council]], ended in 2009, just a few months before the opening of the south stand. The football club took full control of the facilities such as the [[pitch (sports field)|pitch]], seats, [[under-soil heating]] and [[floodlights (sport)|floodlights]], whilst the council retained most of the development rights for the site and manages and receives rent from businesses set up the stadium's main west stand. An artificial playing surface was installed at the stadium in June 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/sport/falkirk-fc/falkirk-are-pitching-in-to-bring-the-bairns-back-to-town-1-2965280#.Ubm-OIhztV8.twitter |title=Falkirk are pitching in to bring the Bairns back to town |work=Falkirk Herald |publisher= |date=13 June 2013 |accessdate=13 June 2013 |first=David |last=Oliver}} In 2016 [[Lowland Football League]] side [[Stirling University F.C.]] started playing their home matches at the ground, having moved from [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion's]] [[Forthbank Stadium]]. In April 2018 it was announced that [[East Stirlingshire F.C.|East Stirlingshire]] would begin playing their home matches at the Falkirk Stadium from the start of the 2018–19 season.{{cite web |url=https://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/sport/football/east-stirlingshire-fc/east-stirlingshire-are-back-in-town-after-decade-at-stenhousemuir-1-4718500 |title=East Stirlingshire are back in town after decade at Stenhousemuir |first=David |last=Oliver |work=Falkirk Herald |publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd |date=4 April 2018 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} The club had previously played in the centre of Falkirk at [[Firs Park]] until 2008, before spending a decade ground-sharing with [[Stenhousemuir F.C.|Stenhousemuir]] at [[Ochilview Park]]. ==Structure and facilities== [[File:Falkirk stadium stands.jpg|300px|thumbnail|right|The three stands of the stadium]] The Falkirk Stadium is an [[all-seater stadium]] which currently consists of three completed stands in the form of the main west stand and smaller north and south stands. Upon the stadium's construction the west stand was the first to be built, and subsequently completed in 2004. The north and south stands were completed in 2005 and 2009 respectively. The west stand has a capacity of roughly 4,200{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/falkirk-keep-rising-from-the-rubble-in-more-ways-than-one-first-division-with-their-community-spirit-and-a-new-stand-the-promotion-favourites-are-planning-a-bright-future-finds-alan-campbell-1.59683 |title=Falkirk keep rising from the rubble in more ways than one |first=Alan |last=Campbell |newspaper=[[The Sunday Herald]] |date=20 March 2005 |accessdate=3 September 2013}}[http://www.talkfootball.co.uk/guides/falkirk_fc_history.html New Home, New Standards], TalkFootball. Retrieved 11 January 2012. and hosts several facilities which have ranged from a nursery to a restaurant. A temporary east stand has been present on several occasions. [[File:Falkirk Stadium South Stand.jpg|thumb|300px|The South Stand.]] ==Other uses== As well as hosting Falkirk F.C., the stadium has also staged several youth level international [[rugby union]] matches. In 2008 the stadium was the venue chosen by the [[Scottish Rugby Union]] to host [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland's]] home matches at the [[Six Nations Under 20s Championship]] which were played against [[England national under-20 rugby union team|England under-20s]] and [[France national under-20 rugby union team|France under-20s]].[https://archive.is/20130201153718/http://www.rbs6nations.com/en/u20/u20s_match-centre_fixtures-results.php?includeref=740&season=2007-2008 U20's Six Nations Fixtures and Results], Retrieved 16 March 2012. Former Falkirk manager [[John Hughes (footballer born 1964)|John Hughes]] had commented on the condition of the pitch which was previously damaged during rugby matches.{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-15351971.html |title=Hughes appeals for an end to rugby at Falkirk Stadium |first=Stewart |last=Fisher |newspaper=[[Sunday Herald]] |date=17 February 2008 |accessdate=3 September 2013}} The stadium is also used on occasion by the [[Scotland women's national football team]] in World and Euro qualifying championships as well as in friendly matches.{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/scots-women-buoyed-by-addition-of-baby-fleeting-to-the-squad-1-798328 |title=Scots women buoyed by addition of baby Fleeting to the squad|date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |work=The Scotsman |publisher=Johnston Publishing}} Also in relation to football, the stadium has hosted the home matches of the [[Scotland national under-21 football team]], the first happening in November 2004 in a game against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]].{{cite news |url=http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/sport/local-sport/pitch-perfect-at-falkirk-stadium-1-298634|title=Pitch-perfect at Falkirk Stadium |first= |last= |newspaper=[[Falkirk Herald]] |date=18 November 2004 |accessdate=3 September 2013}} The Falkirk Stadium hosts summer music concerts, marketed under the "Rock The Stadium" brand.https://twitter.com/RocktheStadium The first act to appear at the Falkirk Stadium was [[Elton John]], on 10 June 2012 as part of his [[Greatest Hits Tour (Elton John)|Greatest Hits Tour]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-15991036 |title=Elton John to play Falkirk Stadium gig |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=1 December 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2012}} In subsequent years, [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]] (23 June 2013),http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/music/music-news/rockers-status-quo-thrilled-after-1494770 [[Midge Ure]] (22 June 2013),http://www.falkirkherald.co.uk/news/local-news/1980s-pop-stars-set-to-rock-falkirk-1-2689319 [[Rod Stewart]] (21 June 2014)http://www.scotsman.com/what-s-on/music/gig-review-rod-stewart-falkirk-1-3452900 [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] (1 August 2015), [[Madness (band)|Madness]] (4th August 2017), [[Jess Glynne]] (5th August 2017) and [[Little Mix]] (27 July 2018) Have Performed ==Transport== The Falkirk Stadium is within a 30-minute walk of [[Falkirk Grahamston railway station]] which is on the main [[Edinburgh to Dunblane Line]] and [[Cumbernauld Line]] from [[Glasgow]]. During weekdays and Saturdays alternate trains between Glasgow and Cumbernauld call at Falkirk Grahamston. Special match day bus services provided by [[First Scotland East]] allow direct transport to the stadium from around the [[Falkirk (council area)|Falkirk area]].[http://www.falkirkfc.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=112&Itemid=142 Falkirk FC - Parking and Travel], ''falkirkfc.co.uk''. Retrieved 16 March 2012. The number 98 service from [[Brightons]] passes through [[Shieldhill, Falkirk|Shieldhill]], [[Glen Village|Hallglen]] and [[Laurieston, Falkirk|Laurieston]] before terminating at the stadium. Access from [[Larbert]] on match days is provided by the number 99 bus, which is destined for the stadium via [[Stenhousemuir]], [[Carronshore]] and [[Bainsford]].[http://www.firstgroup.com/ukbus/scotland_east/journey_planning/timetables/timetable.php?day=1&source_id=2&service=99&routeid=3649371&operator=25&source=sp South East and Central Scotland - Timetables for Service Number: 99], First Scotland East Retrieved 16 March 2012. As well as the special match day routes, regular services are also provided by [[First Scotland East]] from Falkirk bus station to [[Grangemouth]] (routes 3 and 4/4A and 4B) and [[Bo'ness]] (routes 5/5A and 5C) which stop outside the stadium.[http://www.firstgroup.com/ukbus/scotland_east/journey_planning/timetables/index.php?operator=25&page=1&redirect=no South East and Central Scotland - Timetables], First Scotland East Retrieved 16 March 2012. ==See also== * [[History of Scottish football#Stadium moves and refurbishments|Scottish stadium moves]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Falkirk Stadium}} *[http://www.falkirkstadium.co.uk/ Falkirk Stadium official site] *[http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/falkirk.html Falkirk Stadium at the Scottish Ground Guide] {{Falkirk F.C.}} {{East Stirlingshire F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} [[Category:Falkirk F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Falkirk (council area)]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish Premier League venues]] [[Category:Scottish Football League venues]] [[Category:Scottish Professional Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Falkirk]] [[Category:East Stirlingshire F.C.]]
